MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the Electrical Power Subsystem lesson of the Lunar Module Academy.
The EPS is the system responsible for powering everything in the Lunar Module. Power is supplied by five batteries in the descent stage and two in the ascent stage.
Two descent stage batteries (No. 1 and 4) power the LM from T -30 minutes until after transposition and docking, at which time the LM receives electrical power from the CSM.

After separation from the CSM, during the powered descent phase of the mission, four descent stage batteries are paralleled with the ascent stage batteries. Paralleling the batteries ensures minimum required voltage for all LM operations.
During lunar stay, specific combinations of the five descent stage batteries can be paralleled to provide power to the LM.
Before lift-off from the lunar surface, ascent stage battery power is introduced, descent power is terminated, and descent feeder lines are deadfaced and severed.
Ascent stage battery power is then used until after final docking, and the astronauts transfer to the CM.
Primary AC power is provided by two inverters, which supply 115V and 400Hz (synced condition) AC power to the LMs subsystems.
Electrical power is distributed to LM subsystems via the LM Pilot's DC bus, the Commander's DC bus, and AC busses A and B.
In addition to the batteries in the EPS system, the Explosive Devices system (EDS) has two dedicated and isolated batteries solely used for the EDS.
The control panel for the EPS can be found on Panel 14, with switches and gauges used to configure and monitor the various components.
Panels 11 and 16 contain all the circuit breakers, and allows you to connect each individual system available in the LM to the EPS.
The flight manual contains a lot of details on how the EPS is wired to other systems, though in this lesson we'll only learn how to operate it.
First of all, the descent stage batteries No.1 and No.4 have two connection modes, either connected to the low voltage taps, or to the high voltage taps.
During the initial stages of a lunar mission, only the low voltage taps of these batteries are used to power the Lunar Module.
During launch, these low voltage taps are automatically connected, and will be powering the LM until you perform the Subsystems Activation checklist.

You can see if these batteries are online with their high or low voltage taps based on their respective talkback indicators. If it shows LO, the low voltage taps are in use, and GRAY when using the high voltage taps.
Each battery can be connected or disconnected to the electrical system using a switch. Setting it to ON connects it, and OFF/RESET disconnects it.
A talkback indicator above each switch is usually gray when the battery is online, and barberpoled (bp) when offline.

Let's try to disconnect Descent Battery No.1's high voltage taps. On the DESCENT POWER section of Panel 14, set LMP BAT 1 HI-V switch to OFF/RESET.  Also flip the LMP BAT 1 LO-V switch to UP/ON to ensure it is connected. The talkback should indicate LO.
To bring the low voltage tap offline, disconnecting the battery, set the LMP BAT 1 LO-V switch to OFF.
You can monitor the voltage of the battery, and how much amps each is consuming by using the two gauges on the left of Panel 14.

The VOLTS gauge should show 28-37 volts if the battery is healthy. 28-32 vdc is shown with normal and distributed loads. If the battery is at capacity, but has little or zero load (amps), the voltage will be higher.
The AMPS gauge should indicate 0 when the battery is offline, and the consumption rate when online.
The POWER/TEMP MON selector allows you to cycle through each battery, AC and DC buses. Set this to 1.
Battery 1 is now being monitored. The VOLTS gauge should show 28-37 volts, and AMPS should show 0. As we do not have any loads now, the battery should show a voltage of ~37 vdc
Bring the LMP BAT 1 LO-V taps online.
Bring the LMP BAT 1 HI-V taps online.
The AMPS gauge should now indicate a reading above 0, based on the electrical systems in use.
LMP BAT 2 and CDR BAT 3 only have high voltage taps, and get online when their switches are set to ON.
The LUNAR BAT is usually offline during flight. It can be connected to both the CDR's and/or LMP's DC bus(es).
The other batteries are connected to the LMP bus if they indicate LMP (Bat 1 and 2), and CDR if they indicate CDR (Bat 3 and 4)
The ascent stage batteries supply DC power to the LM Pilot's and Commander's busses in essentially the same manner as the descent stage batteries.
The batteries are selected with the ASCENT POWER switches on panel 14. Bat 5 powers the LMP bus and Bat 6 powers the CDR bus. Each can be tied to power either bus.
The battery feeders are connected to the DC busses through the 100-ampere EPS: BAT FEED TIE circuit breakers (panels 11 and 16).
Let's try this now, still focusing on the LMP DC circuit. As mentioned, there are two DC circuits, one for the LMP and one for the CDR.
Set the POWER/TEMP MON selector to LMP BUS to monitor the LMP DC bus.
The LMP powers the Lunar Module pilot side (where Panel 14 is etc), and the CDR side powers the other side.
The LMP batteries are connected to the LMP DC bus by default, and the connection is controlled using the battery switches and the battery feed ties.
Two bat feed ties exist per circuit, BAT FEED TIE A and BAT FEED TIE B. Open the BAT FEED TIE B fuse (the right one) on the EPS section of Panel 16 first.
Next, open the BAT FEED TIE A fuse as well. This will make the LMP's side go dark, as the electrical system that connects LMP Bat 1 and 2 to the LMP DC bus is disconnected.
Now use your flashlight (press F on the keyboard if you use the default mapping).

The VOLTS and AMPS gauge should now read 0 since we opened the BAT FEED TIE circuit breakers, effectively disconnecting the LMP DC bus. The DC BUS light should also be illuminated on the CW (Caution & Warning) panel, indicating that a DC BUS is offline.
On the right side of the BAT FEED TIE fuses, you can see two CROSS TIE fuses. These are used to connect the CDR and LMP DC buses.
Close the CROSS TIE BUS circuit breaker and notice it restores power given that the CDR's BAT FEED TIE circuit breakers are closed. The CDR's DC bus now provides power to the LMP's DC bus.
The VOLTS and AMPS gauge should now indicate that the LMP DC bus is back online.
When both CROSS TIE circuit breakers are opened, the CDR's and LMP DC buses are completely isolated from each other.

Let's switch focus to the AC system. Two inverters exist, where one can be used at the time. The INVERTER switch is used to connect either INVERTER 1 or INVERTER 2 to the electrical system, converting DC power to AC power.
Verify that this switch is set to INV 2 which is the normal position.

The Subsystems Activation checklist disconnects INV 1 from the circuit. Set the INV switch to INV 1, and notice that the integral lights turn off. These lights require AC power, which is currently not provided.

This is because the INV 1 fuse is open, so the inverter is not getting power from the CDR's DC bus. Close the INV 1 fuse on Panel 11 (CDR side) which should bring INV 1 online and bring the lights back up.
You can use the POWER/TEMP MON selector to monitor the AC circuit as well.
You can also monitor the Explosive Devices system by setting the POWER/TEMP MON to OFF/ED.

When in OFF/ED, use the ED VOLTS switch to monitor either ED BATTERY A or B. Set it to A and notice that the volts indicate 37. The normal batteries are 28 volt while the ED batteries are 37 volts. They are used to trigger on-board explosives.

The electrical system in the descent stage is connected to the ascent stage. A deadface mechanism allows you to disconnect the entire electrical system in the descent stage from the ascent stage (where you are now standing).

Set the DES BAT connection switch to DEAD FACE. Notice that the talkbacks indicate barberpole, and that the entire descent stage electrical system is de-powered. This is used when staging into the ascent stage, when taking off from the lunar surface.
If you take a look around inside the cockpit, you can notice that you still have power on the CDR side. The reason for this is that the CSM is powering the CDR bus through the CSM umbilical.
Enter the Command Module, and de-power the power line going from the CSM to the LM by setting the LM PWR switch to OFF.
Now, go back into the Lunar Module and notice that everything is dark. We do not have any power. Use the flashlight and connect NORMAL ASCENT BAT 5.
Then connect the NORMAL ASCENT BAT 6 and notice that the CDR and LMP buses are once again being powered, but now from the ASCENT STAGE batteries instead.
Please also note that the EPS: DISP cb on Panel 16 needs to be closed for the VOLTS and the AMPS gauge on Panel 14 to work.
This concludes the EPS lesson. I know we covered a lot of things, and I recommend you to check the electricity chapter of the Lunar Module Flight Manual.
Good job, and have a good day!

Title: Lesson 3 - Electrical Power
Description: In the previous lessons, you learned how to enter the LM, and how to find the various checklists for activating subsystems. In this lesson, you will learn how the basics of the Electrical Power Subsystem works.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Instructor: Patrick
Level: Advanced

In this lesson, we will go deeper into the Electrical Power Subsystem (EPS). We will learn about the various power sources available, and their modes of operation.
